title: 106_s3129
content: The Act titled "International Debt Forgiveness and International Financial Institutions Reform Act of 2000" may provide debt relief under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative. The Act "International Debt Forgiveness and International Financial Institutions Reform Act of 2000" includes provisions for repealing limitations on earnings from nonpublic gold sales and authorizing appropriations for US contributions to the HIPC Trust Fund. The Act authorizes appropriations for US contributions to the HIPC Trust Fund, with funds remaining available until expended. The Secretary must certify to congressional committees that the Comptroller General has access to necessary information for auditing the Bank and the Fund. The Bank is implementing policies to suspend loans if funds are diverted, prevent loans from displacing private financing, and disburse non-project loans based on specific reforms. The Bank's policies aim to minimize involuntary displacement, promote open markets, focus on projects for economic and social progress, and avoid short-term liquidity financing. The Fund is implementing policies for the suspension of financing if funds are diverted and to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose. Additionally, there are policies in place to measure progress towards graduation from receiving financing on concessionary terms. Policies for Fund financing focus on catalyzing private sector investment, disbursing funds based on specific reforms, promoting open markets, and prioritizing short-term assistance. The Fund focuses on short-term balance of payments financing and policies to measure progress towards graduation from receiving concessionary financing. If access to information is not obtained, the Secretary must report within 30 days. The Secretary must report on the progress of providing access to information by the Bank and the Fund to the Comptroller General within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. If access is denied, the Comptroller General must report to the appropriate congressional committees and the Secretary. The Secretary must report on the progress of providing access to information by the Bank and the Fund to the Comptroller General within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The date specified for submission of the report is the earlier of the date a certification is made under paragraph (1) or, if a certification cannot be made, the date on which a report is submitted under paragraph (2), or 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. STRENGTHENING PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF FUNDS BY MULTILATERAL DEVELOPMENT BANKS. The Secretary is required to instruct the US Executive Director of each multilateral development bank to ensure funds are used as intended. Upon request, the Secretary must provide data to congressional committees on the bank's objectives. The Secretary must submit a report to congressional committees within 30 days explaining the failure to obtain data. A progress evaluation report evaluating efforts to reduce bribery and corruption in multilateral development bank programs must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This report should include improvements in supervision, monitoring, auditing, and country-specific anticorruption programs. The report must detail actions taken to discipline corrupt employees in multilateral development banks and the outcome of efforts to harmonize procurement practices. SEC. 4. REPORTS ON POLICIES, OPERATIONS, AND MANAGEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS. The Comptroller General will submit an annual report on audits of multilateral development banks' financial operations conducted by external entities. The Secretary will also submit an annual report on recipient countries' actions to strengthen governance with assistance from the banks. The International Financial Institutions Act is being amended to report on the progress made by the International Monetary Fund in adopting policies to reduce bribery and corruption and to help countries graduate from reliance on concessionary financing. The Forgiveness and International Financial Institutions Reform Act of 2000 requires reports on debt relief programs and their benefits for poor countries, as well as the impact of debt relief on a country's graduation from reliance on concessionary financing. The Comptroller General must also report on operating expenses within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General must submit a report to congressional committees detailing the salaries, benefits, and operating expenses of international financial institutions for the previous fiscal year. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF BILATERAL FUNDING FOR INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS. Section 209(d) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is repealed. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Bank" refers to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The term "Comptroller General" refers to the Comptroller General of the United States. The term "Fund" refers to the International Monetary Fund. The term "international financial institutions" includes multilateral development banks and the International Monetary Fund. The term "multilateral development banks" is also defined. (6) Multilateral development banks include the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Association, the International Finance Corporation, the Inter-American Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank, the Inter-American Investment Corporation, the African Development Bank, the African Development Fund, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and the Multilateral Investment Guaranty Agency. (7) The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury.
